support_summary: TDP-43 aggregates are decorated with degradation adaptor proteins, and TDP-43 aggregation is a central feature in ALS cases caused by UBQLN2 mutations.

functions.cellular_process: UBQLN2 is a shuttle protein that can deliver ubiquitinated substrates to both the proteasome and the autophagy pathway. It binds directly to the C-terminal region of TDP-43.
functions.effect_description: Overexpression of UBQLN2 enhances the clearance of both full-length TDP-43 and its aggregation-prone C-terminal fragments, thereby reducing their cellular levels.
biological_consequence: TDP-43 aggregation → UBQLN2 binding → Delivery to proteasome/autophagy pathways → Enhanced TDP-43 degradation → Reduced TDP-43 toxicity
specific_effects: Mutations in UBQLN2 are linked to X-linked ALS-FTD and result in TDP-43 pathology.
UBQLN2 co-localizes with TDP-43 aggregates in patient neurons.
Overexpression of UBQLN2 can dramatically lower the levels of overexpressed TDP-43 and its fragments in cell models.
